section.p: Here you will compute \displaystyle \int_0^\pi \sin(x) \; dx using the definition of the Riemann integral.

task.p: Check that in this case x_i = i \Delta x. (For what we are doing, we want everything in terms of \Delta x.)

activity.p: The rest of the work will be to massage this Riemann sum to the point where we can take a limit to evaluate the definite integral.

task.p:

Write down the difference of angles formula for the cosine function. (Look this up if you have to.)
\cos(A-B) =
Replace A-B with a and A+B with b and simplify.
Plug in \displaystyle a = \frac{2i+1}{2} \Delta x and \displaystyle b = \frac{2i-1}{2}\Delta x and simplify.
You should have an equation involving \sin(i \Delta x). Solve your equation for this term.
Use your last result to rewrite the Riemann sum under investigation: \displaystyle \sum_{i=1}^n \sin(x_i) \Delta x.
Factor out all terms which do not contain i. You should be left with a difference of two cosine terms in the summation.
Evaluate that sum. (Hint: It is a telescoping sum. Write out some of the terms to see this. The whole point of all of the previous work was to get our sum to look like a telescoping sum.)
If n \to \infty, what happens to \Delta x?

Express \displaystyle \int_0^\pi \sin(x) \; dx as a limit involving \Delta x. That is, replace \displaystyle \lim_{n \to \infty} with \displaystyle \lim_{\Delta x \to c} for the appropriate value of c.
Draw a picture illustrating what this definite integral represents.
